channel.title: Double Click PATH and CLASSPATH setter
channel.description:
[b]First off, I know Lin made one of these, but this one is fully automated. It finds your most recently installed version of java and retrieves the directory to the JDK. Only thing you have to do is hit the 'Set' button![/b]
[img]http://i54.tinypic.com/51bknt.png[/img]
Upon starting this program, it will look for the JDK directory (via the registry key that is set by Java). If it's unable to find your installation of the JDK, it will pop up a MessageBox telling you about how it couldn't find it. Then, (given that you click OK instead of Cancel) it will open up your browser to the site to download Java.
After downloading Java, click the 'Refresh' button which has become activated on the GUI. This will cause the program to do another scan for the JDK. If after the second attempt it doesn't find it, post on the forums and I'll try to figure out the kinks and bugs.
[b]Note:[/b] to run this, you need .NET 2.0 or higher.
After running this application, both your PATH and CLASSPATH variables will be set.
[b]Download:[/b] [url=http://www.mediafire.com/?855q6rhbp055s4n]Variable Setter[/url]

item.title: Double Click PATH and CLASSPATH setter
item.dc:creator: @demps2k9 demps2k9
item.description:
@demps2k9 wrote:

Try doing it manually using this little list of mine

  • Download the latest JDK 6u25 -
  • Click start -
  • Right click Computer/My computer and choose properties -
  • Choose advanced system settings -
  • Choose Enviroment variables -
  • Click new and user variables for “your account name” -
  • Name it CLASSPATH and as the variable add CLASSPATH=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_25\bin; -
  • Click new again and name it PATH, for the variable add C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_25\bin -
  • Open the compiler in your source, delete everything and add:
    @echo off
    title Compiler
    “C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_25\bin\javac.exe” -d .\bin .\src*.java
    pause -

Read full topic
item.source: Double Click PATH and CLASSPATH setter

item.title: Double Click PATH and CLASSPATH setter
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:12, topic:375110”][quote author=Rix_ link=topic=471074.msg3449240#msg3449240 date=1293630110]
[im]http://images1.memegenerator.net/ImageMacro/4740648/exe-shit-y-u-no-linux-compatible.jpg?imageSize=Medium[/img]
[/quote]Probably because you don’t need to set environmental variables in Linux :P[/quote]

Environment, not environmental…

Also, Linux does have a PATH variable like Windows however on Linux /usr/bin is already in it anyway (if you are using a sane distribution/shell anyway) which is where all of Java’s binaries will go.

Read full topic

item.title: Double Click PATH and CLASSPATH setter
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Evil_ you… What’s the word… Dumbass! That’s it You realize mine auto-detected the Java folder and did exactly what yours does months ago? I’d still recommend using mine since you can see everything going on. The only difference is how your program finds the installation path and what happens when it doesn’t. There’s no real point in doing that because when they’re following the tutorial that brought them here originally, they would’ve already had the JDK installed.

Read full topic
